titleproper.value:
Guide to the Sally Belfrage Papers
                    <num>TAM.189</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Processed by Molly Kovel, 2001.

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T18:52-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Sally Mary Caroline Belfrage (1936-1994) was an independent leftist, world-traveling journalist, and writer born in Hollywood, California. She was the daughter of Cedric Belfrage and Molly Castle, two radical British writers. Her books include: 
                <title render="italic">A Room in Moscow</title>; 
                <title render="italic">Un-American Activities: A Memoir of the Fifties</title>; and 
                <title render="italic">Freedom Summer</title>. The collection includes Belfrage's correspondence, manuscripts and documentation of her creative and political activities. 
                <emph render="bold">NOTE:</emph> Portions of the collection are closed until 2021 (see Access Restrictions note). 
                <emph render="bold">NOTE: This collection is housed offsite and advance notice is required for use.</emph>

p.value: <emph render="bold">NOTE: This collection is housed offsite and advance notice is required for use.</emph>

Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

Series V contains FBI files on Sally and Cedric Belfrage and on Nathan Gregory and Helen Silvermaster (during World War II, Nathan was employed by the U.S. Board of Economic Warfare, and was later accused of being a Soviet spy), which were obtained by Sally Belfrage under the Freedom of Information Act.
